awd_titl_txt: Homotopy Theory of Foliations and Diffeomorphism Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
Foliation theory is a field of mathematics, which is roughly 50 years old, whose object of study is certain decomposition of manifolds into path-connected subsets, called leaves. A foliation looks locally like a decomposition of the manifold as a union of parallel submanifolds of lower dimensions. Such geometric structures naturally arise in physics and geology. And in mathematics the depth and breadth of foliated objects made mathematicians use tools from many different branches of mathematics including differential geometry, homotopy theory, noncommutative geometry, ergodic theory and dynamical systems. The PI intends to use new tools from homotopy theory to investigate the relation between foliations and diffeomorphism groups.

The existence and classification of foliations and the implication of such structures on the global topology of manifolds have been extensively studied in the past five decades. However, there are still many mysteries, perhaps the most important of which in the homotopy theory of foliation is the Haefliger conjecture. Haefliger asked whether all plane fields on a manifold whose dimensions are roughly less than the half of the dimension of the manifold are integrable up to homotopy. It was shown by Mather and Thurston that the homotopy theory of foliations is naturally related to the homological invariants of the diffeomorphism groups made discrete.  But the group homologies of diffeomorphism groups as discrete groups tend to be very large and are poorly understood. On the other hand diffeomorphism group with the Whitney topology is better understood, in particular, Galatius and Randal-Williams' program developed new tools to study the classifying space of these groups with the Whitney topology. The PI's plan is to combine the new homotopy theoretical methods that stem from the evolving field of the moduli space of manifolds with the classical foliation theory to study homological invariants of diffeomorphism groups made discrete.

por.por_cntn:
Foliations on a manifold are structures given by a certain decomposition of the manifold into submanifolds of the same dimension called leaves. For example, for codimension one foliations of 3-manifolds, a foliation locally looks like the leaves of a book. The problem of the existence and uniqueness of certain foliations on manifolds has been translated essentially to a homotopy problem by breakthroughs of Thurston in the 1970s. Although this has been a great achievement, the classifying spaces in foliation theory have a mysterious homotopy type. And still, we know very little about the topology and the homotopy of these spaces. 
Thurston himself related the homotopy type of these mysterious spaces to the group of diffeomorphisms of manifolds. One main outcome of this project was to Thurston's theory can be done equivariantly with respect to the natural action of the diffeomorphism groups. And combine this enhancement of the theory with the newly emerging field of the moduli space of manifolds to study the homology of diffeomorphism groups in a stable range. This in particular has led to a solution to Morita's problem on the homology of diffeomorphism groups of surfaces and also to a generalization of Kotschick-Morita's work on surface symplectomorphisms.
Another main aspect of this project was to improve Thurston's method to prove compactly supported h-principle theorems without having the local data.  This in particular has led to proving Mather-Thurston's theorem in the category of piece-wise linear manifolds and it was used in PI's solution to Epstein's question on the perfectness of PL homeomorphisms for the case of surfaces. 
Because of the interdisciplinary nature of this project, the PI has worked and organized events with experts on the dynamics of diffeomorphisms and with low dimensional topologists. I gave expository lectures in $\mathrm{B}\Gamma$-school in Tokyo, a dynamical system meeting (``CAN") in Chicago, group action seminar at KIAS in Korea. In particular, I collaborated with Kathryn Mann as an expert in the dynamical aspects of diffeomorphisms on group actions on $3$-manifolds. Recently, Mike Freedman and Gael Meigniez made progress by looking at the classical work of Thurston in foliation theory from new angles, and we were invited to IAS for their special program on h-principle this year and the PI gave a talk on new variants of Mather-Thurston's theorem. I was also invited to give a plenary talk on the topic of this proposal in the foliation session of the 36th Summer Topology Conference in Vienna in 2022. 

At Northwestern, I participated in the peer observation group to experience the active-learning strategies in calculus courses and as a mentor volunteered in Graduate Research Opportunities for Women (GROW). In Copenhagen, I gave a short public talk on ``What is topology" on ``Culture day" in Denmark. Regarding the Ph.D. level courses, the PI in the past two years has taught a topic course on ``diffeomorphism groups and foliations" at Northwestern and at the University of Copenhagen, I taught Algebraic topology II. In Copenhagen, I also supervised a master's student on ``boundedness of the Euler class for flat bundles". Regarding organizing events about his research, the PI with S\o ren Galatius has organized a workshop in Copenhagen on ``scissors congruence: then and now" that, because of the COVID, has been postponed.  The PI and Ben McReynolds organized an AMS sectional meeting at Purdue to invite researchers who think about diffeomorphism groups from different angles. I gave a plenary talk in the meeting ``Panorama of Geometry and Topology" aimed at undergraduate students of Iowa and nearby institutions in spring 2021. The goal was to introduce students to modern areas of research in Geometry and Topology and inform them about graduate education in mathematics.
